Subject: Bloat defeated!  (Maybe...)
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=7192225; y=VCX0PRKEfyYY64UliLYhn2VNkz5UG3rliOB26d4dAbgqDeFA_Q
X-Yahoo-Profile: ian_badcoe

Hi,
	OK so this is me just scanning a log-file while the bath fills 
(having left it SLEAT running while I watched CSI - what-do-you-know, 
the daughter did it...)

	But, I implemented the idea I discussed a while ago, of making the 
chance of inheriting unmatched (and excess) genes only 50%, and it 
definitely goes a long way towards preventing out-of-control genome growth...

	I ran 900,000 cycles (call it between 9,000 and 18,000 
generations...) with my "trim-the-dead-wood" code completely 
disabled, and the genomes only reached a size of between 50 and 
60.  This is against the previous breeding regime where only 10,000 
cycles would have been enough to push the size up to around 150 or so...

	Also note the other good effect, that I ran nearly a million cycles 
in just under two hours (CSI was a double bill :-), whereas the old 
scheme used to start getting _a_lot_ slower as the genome size 
increased, mostly due to the longer evaluation time, but possibly 
also due to the cost of breeding all those dud genes over and over... ?

	And the cost of the dead-wood trimming itself used to count, that is 
also slow...

	Of course the big question is, does it still search 
efficiently?  It's a little soon to tell, the score has risen to 86% 
(a PPT-type score) which is low for 900,000 cycles, but since that 
many cycles would previously have taken 4 - 5 DAYS, it's a lot faster 
in real-time (if it holds up when I resume the run).  And since I 
live in real-time (mostly) that sounds like a win to me.

	I'll try to remember to leave it going while I'm at work tomorrow 
and see how it does with another 3 or 4 million cycles.

	Ian
In 15 minutes everybody will be in the future.
